ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An overview of tools and models in studying science of complex systems.

This course provided a great survey of different tools useful in the study of systems with many degrees of freedom, including topics such as bifurcation theory, statistical mechanics, mean-field approximation, renormalization theory and more. Also, the week-and-a-half-ly programming assignments definitely improved by programming (especially plotting) skills.
This course provides a comprehensive overview of techniques for computing in science: differential equations solving, modeling, etc.
Its hard to list all of the interesting techniques that we learned in this class. Its a great class for anyone interested in natural processes, and physics simulation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: each of the topics taught are presented without shirking away from the complicated math behind it, which helped cement the concepts further. The course is also well-structured, and covers a lot of ground each week without simply providing surface-level introductions to each concept. Weaknesses: the biggest downside of this course for me was definitely Prof Korenaga's refusal to share lecture notes, which made it much harder to review and follow along with the concepts discussed in class. Even though we weren't directly tested on these concepts since there was no midterm or final exam, it still would have been nice to have a set of notes to follow along with.

The content is great! Sometimes the context of how the theoretical concepts tie in to the examples (and the theoretical foundation of the applications) is not so well fleshed out, but this is also not the focus of the course. Providing more background for the examples would help with continuity, but maybe isn't necessary

The format of 3 days per week is a little annoying, so going down to two days might be better for most students. I also think the classroom felt a little unwelcoming at times, so maybe spending some time to introduce ourselves at the beginning of the year and forming study groups might help with that.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're interested in some cool techniques that are rather broadly applicable to systems that elude a simple theoretical explanation, take this course. Although Prof Korenaga does keep you on your toes with challenging homework assignments, they truly help you understand the concepts taught, and you will come out of the course with a set of tools that you won't forget for a while to come.
Sure! This course is good for any students looking to understand the intersection of Physics and Computer Science and the mathematics underlying techniques in this intersection
